Functional suitability.description: degree to which a product or system provides functions that meet stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions

Reliability.description: degree to which a system, product or component performs specified functions under specified conditions for a specified period

Performance efficiency.description: performance relative to the amount of resources used under stated conditions

Usability.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use

Maintainability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be modified by the intended maintainers

Security.description: degree to which a product or system protects information and data so that persons or other products or systems have the degree of data access appropriate to their types and levels of authorization

Compatibility.description: degree to which a product, system or component can exchange information with other products, systems or components, and/or perform its required functions, while sharing the same hardware or software environment

Portability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a system, product or component can be transferred from one hardware, software or other operational or usage environment to another

Supplier.description: Description about anyone who provides goods or services to a company or individuals.

Cost.description: Denotes the amount of money that a company spends on the creation or production of goods or services.

Product.description: Description about any article or substance that is manufactured or refined for sale.

Functional appropriateness.description: degree to which the functions facilitate the accomplishment of specified tasks and objectives

Functional completeness.description: degree to which the set of functions covers all the specified tasks and user objectives

Functional correctness.description: degree to which a product or system provides the correct results with the needed degree of precision

Maturity.description: degree to which a system, product or component meets needs for reliability under normal operation

Availability.description: degree to which a system, product or component is operational and accessible when required for use

Fault tolerance.description: degree to which a system, product or component operates as intended despite the presence of hardware or software faults

Recoverability.description: degree to which, in the event of an interruption or a failure, a product or system can recover the data directly affected and re-establish the desired state of the system

Time behavior.description: degree to which the response and processing times and throughput rates of a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements

Resource utilization.description: degree to which the amounts and types of resources used by a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements

Capacity.description: degree to which the maximum limits of a product or system parameter meet requirements

Appropriateness recognizability.description: degree to which users can recognize whether a product or system is appropriate for their needs

Learnability.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals of learning to use the product or system with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in a specified context of use

Operability.description: degree to which a product or system has attributes that make it easy to operate and control

User error protection.description: degree to which a system protects users against making errors

User interface aesthetics.description: degree to which a user interface enables pleasing and satisfying interaction for the user

Accessibility.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by people with the widest range of characteristics and capabilities to achieve a specified goal in a specified context of use

Modularity.description: degree to which a system or computer program is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components

Reusability.description: degree to which an asset can be used in more than one system, or in building other assets

Analyzability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which it is possible to assess the impact on a product or system of an intended change to one or more of its parts, or to diagnose a product for deficiencies or causes of failures, or to identify parts to be modified

Modifiability.description: degree to which a product or system can be effectively and efficiently modified without introducing defects or degrading existing product quality

Testability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established for a system, product or component and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met

Confidentiality.description: degree to which a product or system ensures that data are accessible only to those authorized to have access

Integrity.description: degree to which a system, product or component prevents unauthorized access to, or modification of, computer programs or data

Non-repudiation.description: degree to which actions or events can be proven to have taken place, so that the events or actions cannot be repudiated later

Accountability.description: degree to which the actions of an entity can be traced uniquely to the entity

Authenticity.description: degree to which the identity of a subject or resource can be proved to be the one claimed

Co-existence.description: degree to which a product can perform its required functions efficiently while sharing a common environment and resources with other products, without detrimental impact on any other product

Interoperability.description: degree to which two or more systems, products or components can exchange information and use the information that has been exchanged

Adaptability.description: degree to which a product or system can effectively and efficiently be adapted for different or evolving hardware, software or other operational or usage environments

Installability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be successfully installed and/or uninstalled in a specified environment

Replaceability.description: degree to which a product can replace another specified software product for the same purpose in the same environment

Organizational structure.description: Description of the organizational structure of the supplier company.

Positioning and Strength.description: Description of the position of the supplier company in the market.

Reputation.description: Capability of the supplier to perform similar projects based on past experiences and certifications.

Services Offered.description: Description of the services offered by the supplier.

Support.description: Description of the support mechanisms offered by the supplier.

Licensing Schema.description: Description of the COTS component licensing options.

Licensing Costs.description: Detail of the costs for the different licensing options

Platform Cost.description: Estimation of the cost for the required production platform

Implementation Cost.description: Estimation of implementation costs based on similar past experiences.

Network Cost.description: Estimation of additional cost for network operation.

Stability.description: Attributes of the product that bear on the stability of the product.

Ownership.description: Attributes in relation to the intellectual property rights.

Deliverables.description: Detail of the out of the box and post implementation deliverables.

Parameterization / Customization.description: Attributes in relation to the initial effort required for the product to operate.

Guarantees.description: Detail of the guarantees provided over the product.

Active Community.description: A community generally defined is a group of software practitioners who gathered in a place to achieve a common goal.

Administrative controls.description: Administrative controls are procedure and policy designs that lessen the threat of a hazard to an individual. Administrative controls typically change the behavior of people rather than removing the actual hazard.

Built-in team collaboration.description: Team collaboration is a communication and project management approach that emphasizes teamwork, innovative thinking and equal participation to achieve objectives.

Business Analysts.description: Business Analysts users are people whom have certain knowledge on software development, but are not developers (e.g. knowledge on databases, familiarity with data types such as strings and integers). It is hard to define how much technical knowledge these people require, therefore we simply position this user type as more knowledgeable (regarding software development) than a domain expert, but less than a developer.

Case flow.description: Case flows are more dynamic than processes, in the sense that a state can jump to multiple other states. Case flows are defined as �proceedings that involve actions taken regarding a subject in a particular situation to achieve a desired outcome�. The standard provided by the OMG (2014a) is Case Management Modeling Notation (CMMN).

Close to programming language.description: An expression language such as the one in Excel is relatively close to writing expressions in a programming language.

Code Generation.description: the process by which a compiler's code generator converts some intermediate representation of source code into a form that can be readily executed by a machine.

Company-Branded Templates & Styling.description: The user can customize the UI and add companies logos, templates, and styles.

component catalogue.description: The software components catalogue holds details of the components which are potentially reusable. A cataloguer may enter components in the catalogue, may delete components from the catalogue, and may associate reuse information with a catalogue component in the form of a set of key words.

Connectors to various back-ends or servi.description: Automatically handles data structures, storage, and retrieval.

Convert model to text.description: transforming the model to an XML/JSON format (Model to XML)

Create extensions and widget libraries.description: The platform allows you to create extensions and widget libraries using JS, HTML and Node.js, etc.

Cross-Platform Integration.description: It facilitates systems to share tasks and merge data across other systems flawlessly.

Data mapping.description: Being able to easily map external data formats to the entities used in your application is an important aspect of integration. You define what the message looks like that you are going to use while communicating with external systems. This could be a JSON or XML message based on an example JSON snippet, or an XML message based on an XML Schema (XSD).

Data rules.description: A data rule is an expression that determines the set of legal data that can be stored within a data object. Use data rules to ensure that only values compliant with the data rules are allowed within a data object. Data rules will form the basis for correcting or removing data if you decide to cleanse the data.

Decision table.description: Decision tables are a concise visual representation for specifying which actions to perform depending on given conditions. They are algorithms whose output is a set of actions.

Decision tree.description: A decision tree is a decision support tool that uses a tree-like graph or model of decisions and their possible consequences, including chance event outcomes, resource costs, and utility. It is one way to display an algorithm that only contains conditional control statements.

Domain Experts.description: Domain experts are knowledgeable in business processes and have no technical knowledge.

Entity-Attribute-Relationship (EAR).description: Diagrams created to represent attributes as well as entities and relationships may be called entity-attribute-relationship diagrams, rather than entity�relationship models. Entity-attribute-relationship (EAR) models are similar to BR models, except that EAR models also incorporate a notion of attribute type that is separate from relationship type. Note, Binary Relationship (BR) models basically represent types related to other types.

Expression editor.description: An Expression Editor allows you to edit various Boolean or regular expressions in controls: In this editor, you can type an expression manually, or select functions, operators and operands using the editor's controls. An expression is a string that, when parsed and processed, evaluates some value.

Form & View.description: Form & view: allows modelers to create two kind of pages: (I) forms in which data can be entered/edited and (II) views in which data can be viewed. Within those pages it is only possible to specifically model attributes that will be visible for viewing or alteration. The size and positioning of those fields cannot be altered (except for sequence).

Future Roadmap.description: A roadmap is a strategic plan that defines a goal or desired outcome and includes the major steps or milestones needed to reach it. It also serves as a communication tool, a high-level document that helps articulate strategic thinking�the why�behind both the goal and the plan for getting there.

GDPR.description: The General Data Protection Regulation 2016/679 is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area.

General-purpose platform.description: General-purpose platforms target a wide range of web and mobile applications with extensive collections of declarative tools that address application creation, integration, deployment, life-cycle management, and distribution (through marketplaces).

HIPAA compliant.description: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 was enacted by the 104th United States Congress and signed by President Bill Clinton in 1996.

Identity and permissions management.description: Identity and Access Management governs users by enforcing both authentication and authorization. Authentication verifies a user's identity. Once authenticated, the verified user may use any of the resources their account is authorized to access.

Importing data.description: To use data produced by another application. The ability to import data is very important in software applications because it means that one application can complement another.

Integrate with an ERP system.description: Enterprise resource planning is the integrated management of main business processes, often in real time and mediated by software and technology.

ISO 27001-2013 certification.description: ISO/IEC 27001:2013 is the industry leading standard that specifies the processes to establish, implement, review, monitor, manage and maintain an effective Information Security Management System (ISMS).

Maturity level of the company.description: Maturity level specifies certain characteristics for processes, with higher maturity levels having more advanced characteristics and is a step towards achieving a mature process, providing a set of goals which, when satisfied, places an organization at the next level of maturity.

Mobile app platform.description: Low-code pltaforms which provide some level of support for building and deploying mobile applications.

Mobile Apps.description: A mobile application, also referred to as a mobile app or simply an app, is a computer program or software application designed to run on a mobile device such as a phone, tablet, or watch.

Model interpretation.description: Low-code platforms host the application in such a way that the platform interprets and executes the model at run-time.

Model only (No-code).description: developers use models to develop software, and solely communicate with each other about the system in terms of models (i.e. coding terminology is absent).

Model-centric (Low-code).description: developers use models to develop software, the code is automatically generated.

Multi-channel/Cross-platform Application.description: Multi-Channel Development refers to the ability to use a single development platform to support many different operating systems and methods of deployment. Because there are so many different mobile devices with a wide range of operating systems, which include Android, Windows, iOS, BlackBerry, and more, it has become inefficient for app developers to write code that is specific to each individual operating system. Multi-channel development streamlines both the design and deployment of mobile apps.

Multi-factor authentication (MFA).description: Multi-factor authentication is an authentication method in which a computer user is granted access only after successfully presenting two or more pieces of evidence to an authentication mechanism: knowledge, possession, and inherence. Two-factor authentication is a type, or subset, of multi-factor authentication.

Multilingual Apps.description: The users can localized the UI and build multilingual applications

Native modeling tool.description: the models are interpreted by an executable that runs directly on the computer (native end application)

Natural language rules.description: The use of natural language vs �regular� expression elements. In other words, you can express rules in natural language. For example, instead of using operators such as �<�, �>� and �=�, a modeler can use sentences such as �there are less than�, �there are at least�, �all of the following conditions are true� etc.

OAuth.description: OAuth is an open standard for access delegation, commonly used as a way for Internet users to grant websites or applications access to their information on other websites but without giving them the passwords.

Object-Role Modeling (ORM).description: Object-role modeling (ORM) is used to model the semantics of a universe of discourse. ORM is often used for data modeling and software engineering. An object-role model uses graphical symbols that are based on first order predicate logic and set theory to enable the modeler to create an unambiguous definition of an arbitrary universe of discourse. Attribute free, the predicates of an ORM Model lend themselves to the analysis and design of graph database models in as much as ORM was originally conceived to benefit relational database design.

OData services.description: Open Data Protocol is an open protocol which allows the creation and consumption of queryable and interoperable RESTful APIs in a simple and standard way.

On-premise.description: On-premise software is installed locally, on a company's own computers and servers.

Ontology modeling.description: An ontology encompasses a representation, formal naming and definition of the categories, properties and relations between the concepts, data and entities that substantiate one, many or all domains of discourse.

PCI DSS.description: The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard is an information security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards from the major card schemes. The PCI Standard is mandated by the card brands but administered by the Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council.

Plug and play architecture.description: the plug and play architecture refers to the ability of a computer system to automatically configure expansion boards and other devices. So that, in a plug and play architecture, all interpreters, compilers, generators and exchange formats can be easily replaced.

Popularity in the market.description: the state or condition of being liked, admired, or supported by many people.

Predefined components.description: Predefined components: allows users to model UI predefined components, without the possibility to alter the location, width and height of those UI components.

Private Cloud platform.description: Private clouds are cloud environments solely dedicated to the end user, usually within the user�s firewall. Although private clouds traditionally ran on-premise, organizations are now building private clouds on rented, vendor-owned data centers located off-premise.

Process app platform.description: Low-code platforms for process apps target applications that require coordination and collaboration across different employee and customer roles. These platforms provide a rich mix of process automation, case management, and social interaction features that can be configured to manage structured and unstructured business processes. Low-code platforms for process apps draw their strength from visual process and case-modeling tools that allow teams to visually configure process flow logic and ad hoc task management across a range of internal and external roles, applications, and database systems. These vendors also provide built-in metrics, analytics, and audit trails for monitoring process and case performance.

Process flow.description: Process flows are �descriptions and orderings of work activities across time and space that are designed to yield specific products or services while ensuring the organization�s overall objectives. They provide a conceptual basis for the integration and coordination of distributed resources, tasks, and individuals"". The standard provided by the OMG is BPMN.

Process rules.description: The Process node allow security control rules to be matched with specific requesting processes. Process rules allow you to manage access for an application to run child processes which might otherwise be managed differently in other rules.

Professional Developers.description: Developers are people whom know how to write applications in a programming language (including SQL).

Programmed.description: Developers need to write the business rules using a programming language.

Programming mandatory.description: it is necessary to use a programming language in order to create a fully working application.

Programming optional.description: a full application could be created without any programming, but developers do have the freedom to make use one of the programming languages.

Public Cloud platform.description: The public cloud is defined as computing services offered by third-party providers over the public Internet, making them available to anyone who wants to use or purchase them. They may be free or sold on-demand, allowing customers to pay only per usage for the CPU cycles, storage, or bandwidth they consume.

Real-time Analytics.description: Real time analytics is the analysis of data as soon as that data becomes available. In other words, users get insights or can draw conclusions immediately (or very rapidly after) the data enters their system. Real-time analytics allows businesses to react without delay.

Report and Analytics.description: The built-in reporting features provide ready-to-use process metrics or process stats. The pre-built reports allow you to view, analyze, and collect insights on the workflows. Moreover, the report lists the combined number of requests at each stage like In-progress, completed & rejected. As a result, you can instantly check the workflow status to observe where their blockages are forming and develop an estimated completion time.

Request-handling platform.description: low-code platforms for request-handling apps target applications that accept, process, and track requests. these platforms come from the world of it service management (itsM) solutions and present to developers the core application pattern of itsM � request handling � as a framework customizable with declarative tools. the declarative tools these platforms provide address application creation, workfl ow, deployment, �service� life-cycle management, and distribution (through marketplaces).

REST.description: Representational state transfer is a software architectural style that defines a set of constraints to be used for creating Web services. Web services that conform to the REST architectural style, called RESTful Web services, provide interoperability between computer systems on the Internet.

Service Calls.description: Various integrations allow calling services when a certain event occurs. The most common one is calling a service when an automation trigger happens.

Single Sign-On (SSO).description: Single sign-on is a property of access control of multiple related, yet independent, software systems. With this property, a user logs in with a single ID and password to gain access to any of several related systems.

Smartwatch (wearable) Apps.description: The apps can be sideloaded or installed on smartwatches

SOAP.description: SOAP is a messaging protocol specification for exchanging structured information in the implementation of web services in computer networks. Its purpose is to provide extensibility, neutrality, verbosity and independence.

SOC 1.description: A SOC 1 Report (System and Organization Controls Report) is a report on Controls at a Service Organization which are relevant to user entities' internal control over financial reporting.

SOC 2.description: SOC 2 is an auditing procedure that ensures your service providers securely manage your data to protect the interests of your organization and the privacy of its clients. For security-conscious businesses, SOC 2 compliance is a minimal requirement when considering a SaaS provider.

SOC 3.description: A Service Organization Control 3 (Soc 3) report outlines information related to a service organization's internal controls for security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality or privacy. These five areas are the focuses of the AICPA Trust Services Principles and Criteria.

SQL or NoSQL databases.description: SQL databases are primarily called as Relational Databases (RDBMS) and NoSQL database are primarily called as non-relational or distributed database. SQL databases are table based databases and NoSQL databases are mainly document based, key-value pairs, graph databases or wide-column stores.

Store model locally.description: users have the choice to save the model as byte code on their local machine

Support different stacks.description: A tech stack is defined as the set of technologies an organization uses to build a web or mobile application. It is a combination of programming languages, frameworks, libraries, patterns, servers, UI/UX solutions, software, and tools used by its developers. Supporting multiple technical stacks increase the maintainance work, as modifications have to be applied in all the generators/interpreters for the different stacks.

Tool set.description: Tool set gives modelers access to a what-you-see-is-what-you-get editor, in which access is provided to different UI components. Within such an editor, the user is free to edit the height and width of those elements.

user stories.description: In software development and product management, a user story is an informal, natural language description of one or more features of a software system. User stories are often written from the perspective of an end user or user of a system.

Version control.description: A component of software configuration management, version control, also known as revision control or source control, is the management of changes to documents, computer programs, large web sites, and other collections of information.

Visual IDE.description: An environment for visually defining the UIs, workflows, and data models of your application and, where necessary, adding hand-written code.

Web API.description: A Web API is an application programming interface for either a web server or a web browser. It is a web development concept, usually limited to a web application's client-side (including any web frameworks being used), and thus usually does not include web server or browser implementation details such as SAPIs or APIs unless publicly accessible by a remote web application.

Web applications.description: In computing, a web application or web app is a client�server computer program that the client runs in a web browser. Common web applications include webmail, online retail sales, online banking, and online auctions.

Web modeling tool.description: the models are interpreted by an executable that runs on a server (web end application)

Web portals.description: A web portal is a specially designed website that brings information from diverse sources, like emails, online forums and search engines, together in a uniform way. Usually, each information source gets its dedicated area on the page for displaying information; often, the user can configure which ones to display.

Workflow.description: Workflows are those �process descriptions that can be executed automatically� that specify �activities involving coordinated execution of multiple tasks performed by different processing entities.�

XML/JSON as data storage.description: XML Database is used to store huge amount of information in the XML format.
